articles.headline: News Corp. President Is Leaving
articles.snippet: Peter F. Chernin will leave in June after failing to reach a new contract with the company controlled by Rupert Murdoch.
articles.abstract: Peter F. Chernin will leave in June after failing to reach a new contract with the company controlled by Rupert Murdoch.
articles.lead_paragraph: Peter Chernin, Rupert Murdoch’s longtime top lieutenant, plans to leave News Corporation when his contract expires in June, a move that renews questions of succession at one of the world’s biggest media companies.

articles.headline: Iraq Museum Reopens Six Years After Looting
articles.snippet: With many halls closed and many pieces still missing, the opening reflects how far Iraq’s recovery has to go.
articles.abstract: With many halls closed and many pieces still missing, the opening reflects how far Iraq’s recovery has to go.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Well over half the exhibition halls in Iraq’s National Museum are closed, darkened and in disrepair. And yet the museum, whose looting in 2003 became a symbol of the chaos that followed the American invasion, officially reopened on Monday.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Pressed to Add Billions to Bailouts
articles.snippet: The government is facing pressure from banks, carmakers and a giant insurer despite the billions it has committed to them.
articles.abstract: The government is facing pressure from banks, carmakers and a giant insurer despite the billions it has committed to them.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Edmund L. Andrews, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Mary Williams Walsh.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: As It Falters, Eastern Europe Raises Risks
articles.snippet: Once-vibrant economies have weakened, making it riskier for Western companies to do business.
articles.abstract: Once-vibrant economies have weakened, making it riskier for Western companies to do business.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  Since the fall of the Berlin Wall, the countries of Eastern Europe have emerged as critical allies of the United States in the region, embracing American-style capitalism and borrowing heavily from Western European banks to finance their rise.

articles.headline: A Crisis Is Separating Eastern Europe’s Strong From Its Weak
articles.snippet: Financial problems have reached the Danube, even in a relatively resilient economy like the Czech Republic’s.
articles.abstract: Financial problems have reached the Danube, even in a relatively resilient economy like the Czech Republic’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRAGUE  The owner of some of the Czech capital’s chic restaurants unveiled a novel approach this week to lure business clients to one of his upscale dining rooms: let diners pay what they like.

articles.headline: 3rd Rescue Would Give U.S. 40% of Citigroup
articles.snippet: Nationalization, perhaps a partial one, appears to be inevitable for the financial giant.
articles.abstract: Nationalization, perhaps a partial one, appears to be inevitable for the financial giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nationalization, at least a partial one, seems inevitable for Citigroup. As Washington prepares to tighten its grip on the struggling company, the implications  for the troubled financial giant and the rest of the industry  are starting to sink in.

articles.headline: Across Atlantic, Echoes in R.B.S.’s Lifeline
articles.snippet: The British government’s minority stake in the Royal Bank of Scotland has ballooned to 68 percent.
articles.abstract: The British government’s minority stake in the Royal Bank of Scotland has ballooned to 68 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Is partial nationalization the cure for America’s ailing banks?

articles.headline: Survey Reveals Broad Support for President
articles.snippet: Confidence is high regarding President Obama’s leadership, a New York Times/CBS News poll shows.
articles.abstract: Confidence is high regarding President Obama’s leadership, a New York Times/CBS News poll shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama is benefiting from remarkably high levels of optimism and confidence among Americans about his leadership, providing him with substantial political clout as he confronts the nation’s economic challenges and opposition from nearly all Republicans in Congress, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: The Kindle: Good Before, Better Now
articles.snippet: While the changes in the new Kindle are fairly minor, they’re exactly what was needed to turn a very good electronic book reader into an even better one.
articles.abstract: While the changes in the new Kindle are fairly minor, they’re exactly what was needed to turn a very good electronic book reader into an even better one.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the high-tech industry, you live for the day when your product name becomes a verb. “I Googled him.” “She’s been Photo shopped.”

articles.headline: Fed Chairman Says Recession Will Extend Through the Year
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke walked a line between realism and hope, as home prices and consumer confidence plunged.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke walked a line between realism and hope, as home prices and consumer confidence plunged.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, offered a sober assessment of the national economy and the prospects of recovery to Congress on Tuesday, as reports of plunging housing prices and consumer confidence reinforced the grim outlook.
articles.byline: By Catherine Rampell and Jack Healy
